content:
• Wednesday, December 19, 2018
  • NWL

    Newell Brands +5% as Icahn increases active stake to 9.9%

    • Newell Brands (NASDAQ:NWL) +5.1% after-hours as activist investor Carl Icahn discloses he has raised his stake in the company to 9.9% from a previous holding of 8.3%.
    • An SEC filing shows Icahn and his son Brett bought more than 1M shares last month at $20-$20.50 each.
    • In April, NWL agreed to add four new board members recommended by Carl Icahn, including Brett Icahn.
     
     
     
     
    | 10:15 PM | 40 Comments
  • CE

    Celanese to join S&P 500; shares +4%

    • Celanese (NYSE:CE) +4.4% after-hours on news it will join the S&P 500 effective prior to the open of trading on Dec. 24.
    • CE will replace Express Scripts, which will be acquired by Cigna in a deal expected to close soon.
     
     
     
     
    | 10:08 PM
  • SURF

    SPPI, PENN & MLHR among notable after hour movers

    • Gainers: SURF +18.7%. TLRY +9.7%. MLHR +8.9%. PENN +6.3%. GNBC +5.7%.
    • Losers: SPPI -35.9%. GTHX -23.9%. REVG -11.1%. LMNR -5.0%.
     
     
     
     
    | 5:33 PM
  • NBEV

    New Age Beverages up 3% after hours on Tilray/AB InBev collaboration

    • New Age Beverages (NASDAQ:NBEV) is up 3% after hours on average volume apparently stoked by Tilray's collaboration with AB InBev aimed at non-alcoholic drinks containing THC and CBD.
    • Previously: Tilray teams up with AB InBev in non-alcoholic beverages with THC and CBD; shares up 10% after hours (Dec. 19)
     
     
     
     
    | 4:58 PM | 3 Comments
  • GTHX

    G1 Therapeutics' trilaciclib fails to beat placebo in mid-stage lung cancer study; shares down 24% after hours

    • G1 Therapeutics (NASDAQ:GTHX) slumps 24% after hours on the heels of its announcement of topline data from a Phase 2 clinical trial evaluating trilaciclib, combined with chemo agent topotecan, for the second- and third-line treatment of small cell lung cancer (SCLC).
    • The objective response rate (ORR) was 13.3% (n=4/30), well below 23.1% (n=6/26) for placebo. The disease control rates (responders + stable cancer) were similar, 60.0% for the treatment group and 61.5% for control, as was median progression-free survival (PFS), both 4.2 months. Overall survival had not been reached at data cutoff.
    • The company plans to meet with U.S. and European regulatory authorities to discuss the totality of data and pathways to approval.
     
     
     
     
    | 4:53 PM | 3 Comments
  • RAD

    Rite Aid +8.5% after FY2019 guidance, McKesson pact

    • Rite Aid (NYSE:RAD) jumps 8.5% in after-hours trading FY2019 guidance shows revenue will meet or beat consensus estimate and that the drugstore chain has amended a drug purchasing pact with McKesson (NYSE:MCK).
    • FY2019 guidance: total revenue of $21.8B-$21.95B vs consensus estimate of $21.8B.
    • Adjusted net loss per share of 1 cent-3 cents vs. consensus of break-even.
    • Same-store sales increase of 0.5%-1.0%.
    • Separately, Rite Aid announces an amendment to its drug purchasing agreement with McKesson, "continuing our relationship for an additional 10 years and providing us with competitive drug pricing and operating flexibility that will help drive future growth,” says Rite Aid CEO John Standley
    • Also, a substantially completed refinancing of its revolving credit facility will extend its debt maturities and provide additional liquidity.
    • Conference call at 5:00 PM ET.
    • Previously: Rite Aid beats by $0.01, revenue in-line (Dec. 19)
     
     
     
     
    | 4:40 PM | 21 Comments
  • TLRY

    Tilray teams up with AB InBev in non-alcoholic beverages with THC and CBD; shares up 10% after hours

    • Cannabis producer Tilray (NASDAQ:TLRY) will partner with AB InBev to research non-alcoholic beverages containing tetrahydrocannabinol (THC) and cannabidiol (CBD). The potential commercialization of the drinks will be confined to Canada.
    • Each company plans to invest up to $50M in the effort. Further details are undisclosed.
    • TLRY is up 10% after hours.
    • Peers Cronos Group (NASDAQ:CRON) and Canopy Growth (NYSE:CGC) are both up 1% after hours.
     
     
     
     
    | 4:36 PM | 55 Comments
  • SPPI

    FDA declines accelerated review status for Spectrum's poziotinib for certain lung cancer patients; shares down 31% after hours

    • Spectrum Pharmaceuticals (NASDAQ:SPPI) slumps 31% after hours on the heels of its announcement that the FDA has declined to designate poziotinib a Breakthrough Therapy for EGFR exon 20-positive non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC).
    • Despite the setback for accelerated review, the company says its development plan and timeline remain unchanged. A Phase 2 study in these patients is in process with an estimated primary completion date of June 2022.
     
     
     
     
    | 4:20 PM | 8 Comments
  • RAD

    Rite Aid beats by $0.01, revenue in-line

    • Rite Aid (NYSE:RAD): Q3 Non-GAAP EPS of $0.01 beats by $0.01; GAAP EPS of -$0.02 beats by $0.02.
    • Revenue of $5.45B (+1.9% Y/Y) in-line.
    • Shares +6%.
    • Press Release
     
     
     
     
    | 4:16 PM | 76 Comments
  • FOLD

    New finance chief at Amicus Therapeutics; shares up 4% after hours

    • Amicus Therapeutics (NASDAQ:FOLD) promotes SVP, Finance and Administration Daphne Quimi to Chief Financial Officer succeeding Chip Baird who will depart next quarter. She has been with the company for 11 years.
    • Shares are up 4% after hours.
     
     
     
     
    | 4:13 PM
  • MNKD

    MannKind launches equity offering; shares down 14% after hours

    • MannKind (NASDAQ:MNKD) commences a public offering of stock and warrants. Prices, volume and terms have yet to be announced. Shares are off 14% after hours.
     
     
     
     
    | 4:06 PM | 21 Comments
  • ADI

    Analyst downgrades ADI on near-term risks

    • Morgan Stanley downgrades Analog Devices (NASDAQ:ADI) from Overweight to Equal-Weight with a $100 price target.
    • Analyst Craig Hettenbach says ADI's guidance is well ahead of its peers but those elevated estimates will make it harder for near-term outperformance considering the ongoing semi risks in 2019.
    • ADI shares are down 4.5% to $84.13.
     
     
     
     
    | 3:27 PM | 3 Comments

  • Rough session for high-yield after Fed hike

    • Long-term Treasury rates are falling sharply after the Fed hiked by 25 basis points and signaled the cycle is not yet done.
    • High-yield, however, is headed the other way, with the iShares High Yield Corporate Bond ETF (NYSEARCA:HYG) and the SPDR High Yield Bond ETF (NYSEARCA:JNK) both in the red.
    • Previously: Game of chicken between Fed and stocks (Dec. 19)
     
     
     
     
    | 3:21 PM | 8 Comments
  • MTCH

    Match Group fires comm VP involved in suit

    • Match Group (NASDAQ:MTCH) drops 1.6% after yesterday's The Verge report that the company fired VP of marketing and communications Rosette Pambakian after she participated in a $2B suit against the company.
    • Multiple Tinder employees involved in the lawsuit were fired. In the original suit, Pambakian claimed former Tinder CEO Greg Blatt sexually assaulted her.
    • The Verge obtained an email between Pambakian, Match Group CEO Mandy Ginsberg, and Tinder CEO Elie Seidman where Pambakian said she was subjected to “ongoing intimidation and retaliation” to get her to resign. Pambakian also said she was fired a day before her options vested.
    • Read the full email exchange at The Verge.
     
     
     
     
    | 3:21 PM | 1 Comment

  • Game of chicken between Fed and stocks

    • Portfolio manager Will Slaughter: "I’d say this decision is a disaster ... Markets will throw a tantrum to force Powell to comply."
    • Equity markets have been screaming "uncle," but the Fed isn't hearing it, hiking rates today and signaling more moves next year (though down to two from three). That's still way more than the roughly zero rate hikes short-term interest rate markets have been pricing in.
    • Stock investors are thus hitting the "sell" button post-Fed, sending the Nasdaq down 2.5% and S&P 500 2.0% as Chairman Jay Powell gives his press conference (live coverage here).
    • The yield curve is flattening further, with the 10-year yield all the way down to 2.75% vs. the new Fed Funds rate at 2.25-2.5%. The two-year yield is at 2.64%. The 30-year yield is now below 3% for the first time in four months.
    • ETFs: DIA, CRF, USA, UDOW, DOG, DXD, SDOW, SCHX, ZF, DDM, VV, FEX, JKD, EQL, EEH, IWL, FWDD, EDOW, SYE, JHML, UDPIX, GSEW, ESGL, HUSV
     
     
     
     
    | 3:08 PM | 185 Comments
  • MRIN

    Microcaps mostly among tech movers

    • Gainers: Marin Software (NASDAQ:MRIN) +92%. Sonic Foundry (OTC:SOFO) +23%. Internap (NASDAQ:INAP) +19%. GigaMedia (NASDAQ:GIGM) +11%. Castlight Health (NYSE:CSLT) +9%.
    • Losers: Gridsum Holding (NASDAQ:GSUM) -12%. Veritone (NASDAQ:VERI) -10%. Atomera Incorporated (NASDAQ:ATOM) -9%. Cincinnati Bell (NYSE:CBB) -8%. Veeco Instruments (NASDAQ:VECO) -8%.
     
     
     
     
    | 3:01 PM
  • NVDA

    Semi stocks slide after Fed hike

    • Semi stocks slide after the Fed rate hike with the Philadelphia Semiconductor index down 1%. Top movers include (NVDA -2.7%), (NXPI -3.3%), (AMD -2.1%), and (ON -3.3%).
    • The overall sector (NYSEARCA:XLK) is up 0.6% with the S&P 500 IT index up 0.2% and the Nasdaq 100 up 0.3%.
    • Related broad tech ETFs: XLK, VGT, TECL, FTEC, IYW, ROM, QTEC, RYT, FNG, TECS, IGM, FXL, XNTK, REW, JHMT, XITK.
    • Previously: The Federal Reserve raises interest rates - neutral rate estimate moves lower (Dec. 19)
    • Previously: Fed trims growth, inflation, rate outlooks (Dec. 19)
     
     
     
     
    | 2:39 PM | 57 Comments

  • Emerging markets give up gains after Fed

    • Up more than 1% prior to the FOMC announcement, the iShares MSCI Emerging Markets ETF (NYSEARCA:EEM) is now about flat on the session.
    • The Fed hiked 25 basis points and indicated the need for continued rate increases in 2019 - disappointing many who had expected the language to hint that a pause in the cycle was at hand.
    • Previously: Fed mostly sticks to its guns, stocks head lower (Dec. 19)
    • ETFs: EEM, VWO, IEMG, EDC, SCHE, EDZ, EMF, MSF, ADRE, EEV, EUM, EET, SPEM, EEME, XSOE, DBEM, FEM
     
     
     
     
    | 2:31 PM | 3 Comments

  • Ten-year yield slides after surprise Fed hawkishness

    • The Fed minutes ago surprised most, hiking rates another 25 basis points, and indicating it continues to see the need for further tightening of policy.
    • Stocks have given up big early gains and the 10-year Treasury yield has whooshed four basis points lower to 2.79%. TLT +1.1%, TBT -2.2%
    • It's not all hawkishness though - the Fed now expects just two rate hikes in 2019 vs. three previously.
    • A check of the dollar (UUP]], UDN) finds it higher post-Fed but still in the red for the day. Gold (NYSEARCA:GLD) has given up its gains, now down 0.35% on the session.
    • Previously: Fed mostly sticks to its guns, stocks head lower (Dec. 19)
    • ETFs: TLT, TBT, TMV, TBF, EDV, TMF, TTT, ZROZ, VGLT, TLH, UBT, SPTL, DLBS, VUSTX, TYBS, DLBL-OLD, OPER
     
     
     
     
    | 2:19 PM | 94 Comments
  • TGE

    Tallgrass Energy and Ramaco Resources among Energy/Materials gainers; FTS International and Key Energy Services among losers

    • Gainers: Tallgrass Energy (NYSE:TGE) +14%. Ramaco Resources (NASDAQ:METC) +12%. Calumet Specialty Products Partners (NASDAQ:CLMT) +12%. Marrone Bio Innovations (NASDAQ:MBII) +11%. Baytex Energy (NYSE:BTE) +10%.
    • Losers: FTS International (NYSE:FTSI) -13%. Key Energy Services (NYSE:KEG) -9%. PEDEVCO (NYSEMKT:PED) -9%. Pacific Ethanol (NASDAQ:PEIX) -8%. Golden Star Resources (NYSEMKT:GSS) -8%.
     
     
     
     
    | 2:00 PM
  • ABBV

    AbbVie teams up with Voluntis in companion digital therapeutics

    • AbbVie (ABBV +2.1%) will collaborate with healthcare software developer Voluntis to develop a solution designed to enhance the coordination of patient care in immunology via digital therapeutic software.
    • The French firm will leverage its Theraxium technology that helps patients self-manage their symptoms via a smartphone app. It is collaborating with Roche (OTCQX:RHHBY -1%) in hemophilia and AstraZeneca (AZN +0.4%) in cancer.
    • Financial terms are not disclosed.
     
     
     
     
    | 1:48 PM | 1 Comment
  • FTNW

    FTE Networks announces stock buyback program

    • FTE Networks (FTNW +9.2%) board has approved a stock repurchase program of up to $4M of the Company’s outstanding common stock, beginning Dec. 19, 2018.
    • The stock buyback program is effective for a three-year period.
     
     
     
     
    | 1:43 PM
  • MHLD

    Maiden Holdings leads financial gainers; Medley Management and Noah Holdings among losers

    • Gainers: Maiden Holdings (NASDAQ:MHLD) +9%. Kingstone Companies (NASDAQ:KINS) +7%. American International Group (NYSE:AIG) +6%. LM Funding America (NASDAQ:LMFA) +6%. Government Properties Income Trust (NYSE:GOV-OLD) +6%.
    • Losers: China Rapid Finance (NYSE:XRF) -18%. CBL & Associates Properties (NYSE:CBL) -6%. Medley Management (NYSE:MDLY) -5%. Noah Holdings (NYSE:NOAH) -5%.
     
     
     
     
    | 1:00 PM
  • MRIN

    Microcaps mostly among midday movers

    • Gainers: Marin Software (NASDAQ:MRIN) +55%. Adial Pharmaceuticals (NASDAQ:ADIL) +22%. Internap (NASDAQ:INAP) +19%. ABM Industries Incorporated (NYSE:ABM) +18%. AutoWeb (NASDAQ:AUTO) +18%. Limbach Holdings (NASDAQ:LMB) +17%. Winnebago Industries (NYSE:WGO) +17%. China Automotive Systems (NASDAQ:CAAS) +16%. Cellect Biotechnology (NASDAQ:APOP) +14%. Motus GI Holdings (NASDAQ:MOTS) +14%.
    • Losers: Surface Oncology (NASDAQ:SURF) -33%. Biocept (NASDAQ:BIOC) -27%. China Rapid Finance (NYSE:XRF) -16%. PLx Pharma (NASDAQ:PLXP) -14%. Gridsum Holding (NASDAQ:GSUM) -14%. ASLAN Pharmaceuticals (NASDAQ:ASLN) -14%. Fortress Biotech (NASDAQ:FBIO) -13%. FTS International (NYSE:FTSI) -13%. Forty Seven (NASDAQ:FTSV) -13%. Allakos (NASDAQ:ALLK) -12%.
     
     
     
     
    | 12:42 PM | 1 Comment
  • FB

    D.C. AG files suit against Facebook (update)

    • The attorney general for the District of Columbia filed suit against Facebook (NASDAQ:FB) for allowing Cambridge Analytica to access personal data without permission, according to The Washington Post sources.
    • A source says the suit is likely to be amended in the future with other, more recent allegations of improper data use.
    • Facebook shares are down 4% to $137.72.
    • Previously: Another personal data scandal for Facebook (update) (Dec. 19)
    • Update: AG Karl Racine confirms the suit with a press release.
     
     
     
     
    | 12:40 PM | 179 Comments
  • BNFT

    Analysts positive on Benefitfocus after event; BNFT +5.5%

    • Benefitfocus (NASDAQ:BNFT) gains 5.5% on positive analyst comments following the company's investor event.
    • Wedbush analyst Daniel Ives has increased confidence in the company's "ability to hit its strong 2019 guidance." Rating is Outperform with a $57 price target.
    • Raymond James analyst Brian Peterson thinks investors should take comfort in the 2019 forecast looking "achievable (if not conservative)." Rating at Outperform with a $58 target.
    • Source: Bloomberg First Word.
     
     
     
     
    | 12:32 PM
  • CI

    New Jersey on board with Cigna/Express Scripts tie-up

    • Cigna (CI +2.8%) reports that the state of New Jersey has signed off on its planned merger with Express Scripts (ESRX +1.9%).
    • The transaction should close tomorrow.
     
     
     
     
    | 12:10 PM | 1 Comment
  • OREXQ

    Orexigen up 32% on expanded Contrave distribution in Asia

    • Thinly traded nano cap Orexigen Therapeutics (OTCPK:OREXQ +31.6%), a wholly owned subsidiary of Nalpropion Pharmaceuticals, is up, albeit on only 11K shares, on the heels of its agreement with iNova for exclusive commercialization rights to Contrave (naltrexone HCl/bupropion HCl extended-release) in additional countries in Southeast Asia, Africa and the Pacific, adding market opportunity to its existing territory of Australia, New Zealand and South Africa.
    • Under the terms of the deal, Orexigen will receive $23M upon closing and will supply product at an undisclosed transfer price.
     
     
     
     
    | 12:06 PM
  • WGO

    General Mills and Winnebago Industries among consumer gainers

    • Gainers: Winnebago Industries (NYSE:WGO) +16%. China Automotive Systems (NASDAQ:CAAS) +9%. General Mills (NYSE:GIS) +7%. LCI Industries (NYSE:LCII) +6%. Naked Brand Group (NASDAQ:NAKD) +6%.
     
     
     
     
    | 12:02 PM
  • DNOW

    NOW -2.8% as Stifel steps to sidelines

    • Stifel downgrades NOW (NYSE:DNOW) from Buy to Hold and cuts the target by $4 to $13.
    • The firm feels positive on management and longer-term potential, but there's too much uncertainty to justify a Buy rating.
    • NOW shares are down 2.8% to $11.45.
     
     
     
     
    | 12:00 PM
  • ADMA

    ADMA Bio up 9% waiting for FDA response to Bivigam BLA amendment

    • Thinly traded micro cap ADMA Biologics (ADMA +9%) is up on modestly higher volume. Investors are expecting good news from the FDA on the company's BLA amendment for BIVIGAM (intravenous immune globulin [human], 10%) which, if approved, will clear the way for a relaunch early next year.
    • Production was shut down to allow time to upgrade and renovate the production facility.
    • The agency's action date was October 25, but was extended until yesterday to allow for the review of additional information submitted by the company at the agency's request.
     
     
     
     
    | 11:56 AM | 1 Comment
  • PTE

    PolarityTE up 11% on SkinTE adoption by Cleveland healthcare network

    • PolarityTE (PTE +10.6%) is up on below-average volume in response to its announcement that its SkinTE autologous human cellular and tissue-based product is now available throughout the University Hospital network in northern Ohio that includes 18 hospitals, more than 40 outpatient clinics and 200 physician offices.
    • Previously: PolarityTE on go with U.S. commercialization of lead candidate SkinTE (Oct. 3, 2017)
     
     
     
     
    | 11:40 AM | 1 Comment
  • CIVI

    Civitas up 12% on $17.75/share takeover bid

    • Thinly traded Civitas Solutions (CIVI +12.4%) is up on whopping 97x surge in volume following at $17.75/share takeover bid from Centerbridge Partners L.P., valuing the company at ~$1.4B.
     
     
     
     
    | 11:28 AM
  • AXTA

    Coating stocks on the rise as Axalta guidance in-line with consensus

    • Coating stocks gain in late morning trading after Axalta's (AXTA +5%) 2019 guidance, in-line with buyside expectations, came in more positive than some peers, RBC analyst Arun Viswanathan wrote in a note.
    • Other paint and coatings makers rising: PPG Industries (PPG +2.4%), Sherwin-Williams (SHW +1.8%), and RPM International.(RPM +0.9%).
    • Source: Bloomberg First Word.
    • Previously: Axalta Coating Systems beats by $0.03, misses on revenue (Oct. 25)
     
     
     
     
    | 11:18 AM
  • AIMT

    Aimmune launches late-stage study of AR101 in young children; shares up 3%

    • Aimmune Therapeutics (AIMT +2.5%) initiates a Phase 3 clinical trial, POSEIDON, evaluating peanut allergy candidate AR101 in peanut-allergic children ages 1-3 years.
    • The primary endpoint of the 105-subject study is the proportion of patients who can tolerate at least 600 mg of peanut protein (~two kernels) with no more than mild allergic symptoms during a food challenge. The estimated primary completion date is November 2020.
    • An earlier Phase 3, PALISADE, in young people aged 4-17 showed that 85% of those who completed the study tolerated the challenge dose of 500-600 mg of peanut protein.
     
     
     
     
    | 11:09 AM | 4 Comments
  • SF

    Stifel slumps after Wells Fargo cuts on pessimistic 2019 outlook

    • Stifel Financial (SF -1.4%) sank as much as 3.9% after Wells Fargo cuts its rating to market perform from outperform, saying Q4 "is likely to represent the peak for profit margins this cycle."
    • Analysts led by Christopher Harris write that net interest, asset management and investment banking revenue may "slow substantially during the next year because of weaker equity markets, fewer interest rate increases and a less favorable capital markets backdrop."
    • Sees double-digit percentage declines for institutional brokerage revenue in 2019 and 2020.
    • Price target cut to $44 from $49.
    • Source: Bloomberg First Word.
    • Analyst ratings.
    • Previously: Stifel boosts stock buyback (Nov. 13)
     
     
     
     
    | 11:05 AM | 1 Comment
  • ADIL

    Aduro BioTech and PolarityTE among healthcare gainers; Biocept and Fortress Biotech among losers

    • Gainers: Adial Pharmaceuticals (NASDAQ:ADIL) +16%. Motus GI Holdings (NASDAQ:MOTS) +13%. Aduro BioTech (NASDAQ:ADRO) +13%. PolarityTE (NASDAQ:PTE) +13%. Civitas Solutions (NYSE:CIVI) +12%.
    • Losers: Surface Oncology (NASDAQ:SURF) -31%. Biocept (NASDAQ:BIOC) -28%. Fortress Biotech (NASDAQ:FBIO) -13%. Sophiris Bio (NASDAQ:SPHS) -10%. Provention Bio (NASDAQ:PRVB) -10%.
     
     
     
     
    | 11:04 AM
  • MSFT

    Mellanox +4% on report of Microsoft acquisition interest

    • Microsoft (MSFT +1.5%) is considering acquiring Mellanox (NASDAQ:MLNX), according to The Marker via The Times of Israel.
    • Goldman Sachs is reportedly managing negotiations.
    • Microsoft is a client of Mellanox's server and storage switch solutions.
    • As always with deal rumors, take details with a grain of salt.
    • Last month, CNBC reported that Xilinx (XLNX +0.2%) was working with Barclays on a potential Mellanox acquisition.
    • Mellanox shares are up 4.3% to $92.72.
     
     
     
     
    | 10:45 AM | 6 Comments
  • JBL

    Analysts adjust Jabil targets after earnings

    • RBC Capital maintains a Sector Perform rating on Jabil (NYSE:JBL) but raises the target from $29 to $30.
    • Analyst Amit Daryanani views the earnings results as strong but notes that Q2 guidance implies a 40 percentage point Y/Y decrease decline in operating margins due to new business costs.
    • More action: Stifel maintains a Hold rating on Jabil and lowers the target from $30 to $27 citing lower multiples and new program ramp risks.
    • Source: StreetAccount.
    • Jabil shares are up 6.8% to $23.75.
    • Previously: Jabil +10% on Q1 beats, upside revenue guide (Dec. 18)
     
     
     
     
    | 10:32 AM
  • AIR

    AAR Corporation down 6% post Q2 results; lowers FY revenue guidance

    • AAR (AIR -6%) reported Q2 sales growth of 17.3% Y/Y to $493.3M, due to continued growth in company’s trading, distribution and programs activities.
    • Sales by segments: Aviation Services $462.9M (+18.2% Y/Y) and Expeditionary Services $30.4M (+5.2% Y/Y).
    • Commercial customer sales contribute 68% to total sales, and government and defense customer contribution was 32%.
    • Q2 Gross margin declined by 94 bps to 18.9% and operating margin declined by 178 bps to 3.4%.
    • SG&A margin declined by 160 bps to 10%.
    • Adj. EBITDA increased 15.3% Y/Y to $40.8M and margin declined by 15 bps to 8.3%.
    • FY19 Guidance: Revenue $2-2.1B (prior $2.1-2.2B); Adj. EPS $2.5-2.8 and Adj. EBITDA $180-190M.
    • Previously: AAR beats by $0.02, misses on revenue (Dec. 18)
    • Transcript
     
     
     
     
    | 10:31 AM

  • Crude inventory declines slightly

    • EIA Petroleum Inventories: Crude -0.5M barrels vs. -2.4M consensus, -1.2M last week.
    • Gasoline +1.8M barrels vs. +1.2M consensus, +2.1M last week.
    • Distillates -4.2M barrels vs. +0.6M consensus, -1.5M last week.
    • Futures +2.21% to $47.63.
    • ETFs: USO, OIL, UCO, SCO, BNO, DTO, DBO, USL, DNO, SZO, OLO, OLEM
     
     
     
     
    | 10:31 AM | 49 Comments
  • LRCX

    Chip stocks stable after Micron earnings

    • Chip stocks aren't taking much of a hit from Micron's earnings report yesterday with Lam Research (LRCX +1.4%) and Applied Materials (AMAT +1%) reversing aftermarket losses. The Philadelphia Semiconductor Index is up a slight 0.1%.
    • Related semiconductor ETFs: SOXL, SOXX, SMH, USD, PSI, XSD, SOXS, SSG, FTXL, XTH
    • Previously: Micron -7% on mixed Q1, downside guide, capex cut (Dec. 18)
     
     
     
     
    | 10:20 AM | 7 Comments
  • SCS

    Steelcase reports Q3 results; shares +2%

    • Steelcase (SCS +2%) reports Q3 sales increase 16.7% Y/Y to $901M & 13% Y/Y on an organic basis led by all growth across Americas & EMEA due to strong project business from both large and small customers; orders increases 10% Y/Y.
    • Sales by segment: Americas: $638.6M (+15.5% Y/Y & organic +12%); EMEA: $170.9M (+21.1% Y/Y & organic +12%) & Others: $91.5M (+17% Y/Y & organic +20%)
    • Gross margin declined 160 bps to 30.9%; decreased by 190 bps in the Americas & EMEA decreased by 60 bps.
    • Operating margin expanded 30 bps to 5%.
    • The company's acquisition of Orangebox Group was completed on September 19, 2018, and was funded by $78.9M of borrowings under the company's global committed bank facility.
    • Total liquidity aggregated $205.7M and total debt was $321.4M.
    • Declared a quarterly cash dividend of $0.135/share payabe on or before January 14, 2019.
    • Q4 Outlook: Sales of ~$860M-885M; expected organic growth of 9-12%; EPS $0.24-0.28.
    • Previously: Steelcase beats by $0.06, beats on revenue (Dec. 18)
    • Previously: Steelcase declares $0.135 dividend (Dec. 18)
     
     
     
     
    | 10:13 AM
  • GDDY

    GoDaddy +3% on Citi start at Buy

    • Citi transfers GoDaddy (NYSE:GDDY) coverage to analyst Nicholas Jones who gives the stock a Buy rating and $82 target.

  • FB

    Another personal data scandal for Facebook (update)

    • Update: Facebook has a blog post responding to the NYT report. Key quote: "None of these partnerships or features gave companies access to information without people's permission, nor did they violate our 2012 settlement with the FTC."
    • Netflix releases a statement about its alleged participation: “At no time did we access people’s private messages on Facebook or ask for the ability to do so."
    • Facebook (NASDAQ:FB) gave other tech companies more access to user personal data than was previously disclosed, according to hundreds of pages of documents obtained by the New York Times.
    • Facebook user friends were visible in Microsoft Bing searches without permission, Netflix and Spotify could access Facebook messages, Amazon had user names and contact information through friends, and Yahoo could see shared friends posts, a practice Facebook said it ended, but Yahoo could still access as of the summer.
    • Facebook tells Axios: "Facebook’s partners don't get to ignore people’s privacy settings, and it’s wrong to suggest that they do."
    • Facebook shares are down 1.9% premarket to $141.
     
     
     
     
    | 7:22 AM | 122 Comments
